1.text: Now Abraham had taken another wife, named Keturah,

2.text: and she bore him Zimran, Jokshan, Medan, Midian, Ishbak, and Shuah.

3.text: Jokshan was the father of Sheba and Dedan. And the sons of Dedan were the Asshurites, the Letushites, and the Leummites.

4.text: The sons of Midian were Ephah, Epher, Hanoch, Abida, and Eldaah. All these were descendants of Keturah.

5.text: Abraham left everything he owned to Isaac.

6.text: But while he was still alive, Abraham gave gifts to the sons of his concubines and sent them away from his son Isaac to the land of the east.

7.text: Abraham lived a total of 175 years.

8.text: And at a ripe old age he breathed his last and died, old and contented, and was gathered to his people.

9.text: His sons Isaac and Ishmael buried him in the cave of Machpelah near Mamre, in the field of Ephron son of Zohar the Hittite.

10.text: This was the field that Abraham had bought from the Hittites. Abraham was buried there with his wife Sarah.

11.text: After Abraham’s death, God blessed his son Isaac, who lived near Beer-lahai-roi.

12.text: This is the account of Abraham’s son Ishmael, whom Hagar the Egyptian, Sarah’s maidservant, bore to Abraham.

13.text: These are the names of the sons of Ishmael in the order of their birth: Nebaioth the firstborn of Ishmael, then Kedar, Adbeel, Mibsam,

15.text: Hadad, Tema, Jetur, Naphish, and Kedemah.

16.text: These were the sons of Ishmael, and these were their names by their villages and encampments—twelve princes of their tribes.

17.text: Ishmael lived a total of 137 years. Then he breathed his last and died, and was gathered to his people.

18.text: Ishmael’s descendants settled from Havilah to Shur, which is near the border of Egypt as you go toward Asshur. And they lived in hostility toward all their brothers.

19.text: This is the account of Abraham’s son Isaac. Abraham became the father of Isaac,

20.text: and Isaac was forty years old when he married Rebekah, the daughter of Bethuel the Aramean from Paddan-aram and the sister of Laban the Aramean.

21.text: Later, Isaac prayed to the LORD on behalf of his wife, because she was barren. And the LORD heard his prayer, and his wife Rebekah conceived.

22.text: But the children inside her struggled with each other, and she said, “Why is this happening to me?” So Rebekah went to inquire of the LORD,

23.text: and He declared to her: “Two nations are in your womb, and two peoples from within you will be separated; one people will be stronger than the other, and the older will serve the younger.”

24.text: When her time came to give birth, there were indeed twins in her womb.

25.text: The first one came out red, covered with hair like a fur coat; so they named him Esau.

26.text: After this, his brother came out grasping Esau’s heel; so he was named Jacob. And Isaac was sixty years old when the twins were born.

27.text: When the boys grew up, Esau became a skillful hunter, a man of the field, while Jacob was a quiet man who stayed at home.

28.text: Because Isaac had a taste for wild game, he loved Esau; but Rebekah loved Jacob.

29.text: One day, while Jacob was cooking some stew, Esau came in from the field and was famished.

30.text: He said to Jacob, “Let me eat some of that red stew, for I am famished.” (That is why he was also called Edom.)

31.text: “First sell me your birthright,” Jacob replied.

32.text: “Look,” said Esau, “I am about to die, so what good is a birthright to me?”

33.text: “Swear to me first,” Jacob said. So Esau swore to Jacob and sold him the birthright.

34.text: Then Jacob gave some bread and lentil stew to Esau, who ate and drank and then got up and went away. Thus Esau despised his birthright.
